note:
Colonisers apply the name *Pima* to the Akimel O'odham.

*'Pima' is the common name applied to us, but it is not something we called ourselves prior to European arrival.*

The Gadsden Purchase. The U.S. purchases additional lands claimed by Mexico to establish the U.S. and Mexico border as we know it today. The purchased area includes the Gila River and lands occupied by Akimel O'odham and Piipaash villages.

Long-term epidemiological study begins among the Akimel O'odham (who are referred to as Pima) focusing on type 2 diabetes and obesity. Research was supposed to last for ten years but continued for more than forty despite the observational nature of the study meaning it had not yielded any findings that directly benefited its participants.
The UCI Machine Learning Repository, an archive of datasets, is created by David Aha and several other graduate students at UCI.
The *Pima Indians Diabetes Data Set* is donated to the UCI Repository with Vincent Sigillito listed as the donor of the database.

The Health Care Research Ordinance is enacted by the Gila River Indian Community. The ordinance states that *'the Community Council has found that Medical and Health Care Research has been conducted in ways that do not respect the human dignity of human subjects and that do not recognize the legitimate interest of the Community in the integrity and preservation of its culture.'*

Dataset is reported missing from UCI Repository. The owners of the PIMA dataset replaced the files with a statement that says *'Thank you for your interest in the Pima Indians Diabetes dataset. The dataset is no longer available due to permission restrictions.'*
Copies of the database remain online and in use.
